title: $A recovers after greenback flies up
text:
Fri, Jul 17, 2015, 5:30 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A recovers after greenback flies up AAP â€“ 15 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has bounced back following a greenback rally in the wake of Greece's creditor deal. 
At 1700 AEST on Friday, the currency was trading at 74.08 US cents, up from 73.81 cents on Thursday. 
Western Union Business Solutions currency strategist Steven Dooley said the Aussie has been under a lot of pressure. 
"It's been a terrible week for the Aussie dollar, yesterday (it was) trading at new six-year lows," he said. 
"Now that the Greek debt crisis is behind us, we've seen markets instantly rebuild their favourite trade - that is short euro, long US dollar." 
Mr Dooley said the local currency was feeling the effects of the carry trade, where investors borrow cheaply in one currency to invest in higher yielding currencies such as the greenback. 
"It resurfaces when markets calm down," he said. 
"What we've seen is the euro go lower, and the US dollar fly back into strength." 
Overnight, the European Central Bank boosted its cash lifeline to Greece after Athens passed a tough reform package demanded by creditors. 
CURRENCY SNAPSHOT AT 1700 AEST ON FRIDAY 
One Australian dollar buys: 
* 74.08 US cents, from 73.81 cents on Thursday 
* 91.88 Japanese yen, from 91.39 yen 
* 68.05 euro cents, from 67.52 euro cents 
* 113.35 New Zealand cents, from 113.10 NZ cents 
* 47.29 British pence, from 47.23 pence 
(*Currency closes taken at 1700 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
